diff. hetero.
references: The test accuracy results along with the 95% confidence intervals are reported in Table 1. For MNIST dataset, both Per-FedAvg methods achieve a marginal gain compared to FedAvg. However, the achieved gain from using Per-FedAvg (HF) compared to FedAvg is more significant for CIFAR-10 dataset. In particular, we have three main observations here: (i) For α=0.001𝛼0.001\alpha=0.001 and τ=10𝜏10\tau=10, Per-FedAvg (FO) and Per-FedAvg (HF) perform almost similarly, and better than FedAvg. In addition, decreasing τ𝜏\tau leads to a decrease in the performance of all three algorithms, which is expected as the total number of iterations decreases. (ii) Next, we study the role of α𝛼\alpha. By increasing α𝛼\alpha from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.010.010.01, for τ=4𝜏4\tau=4, the performance of Per-FedAvg (HF) improves, which could be due to the fact that model adapts better with user data at test time. However, as discussed above, for larger α𝛼\alpha, Per-FedAvg (FO) performance drops significantly. (iii) Third, we examine the effect of changing the level of data heterogeneity. To do so, we change the data distribution of half of the users that have a/2𝑎2a/2 images from one of the first five classes by removing these images from their dataset. As the last line of Table 1 shows, Per-FedAvg (HF) performs significantly better that FedAvg under these new distributions, while Per-FedAvg (FO) still suffers from the issue we discussed in (ii). In summary, the more accurate implementation of Per-FedAvg, i.e., Per-FedAvg (HF), outperforms FedAvg in all cases and leads to a more personalized solution.
